properties.name: Zanzibar, Tanzania
properties.type: The Monkey, the Shark, and the Washerman’s Donkey
properties.location: Island of Unguja, colloquially known as Zanzibar Island, is located off the coast of Tanzania and is just south of Kenya.
properties.facts:
This is a myth about the freindship and betrayal of a monkey and a shark. The tale begins with the blossoming of freindship between the mokey and the shark. The monkey would drop down fruit for the shark to eat, and the shark eventually comes to invite the monkey to a feast under the sea. 
 
 However, when the monkey learns of the shark's true intentions to take the monkey's heart, the monkey strikes back with a trick to get the shark to bring him back to the tree. 
 
 This story does not portray sharks or monkeys as evil, and shines a neutral light on the both of them. 
 
 In Tanzania, the respect held for the ocean and for sharks can be seen in the fact that 96% of total marine production is from small, artesinal fisheries. 
 
 Although there is underreporting due to a lack of government fish landing beach recorders, it can be seen that the older style of catching fish and sharks that the people of Tanzania have is more sustainable than commercial fisheries.

properties.name: Martha's Vineyard
properties.location: Off the coast of Cape Cod, Massachusetts lives the Island of Martha's Vineyard.
properties.facts: Steven Spielberg's infamous movie Jaws is set in this New England vacation haven. Jaws is a movie chronicaling the tale of a massive killer shark that terrorizes the residents of a seaside town. The movie paints the shark in a terrible light, showing it as mysterious, muderous, and malicous. Jaws<\i> came out on June 20th, 1975, just in time for the summer festivities of the beach. This movie is regarded as one of the best horror films of all time and is one of the largest phenomena of pop culture influencing environmental health that we have on record. The amount of sharks caught and killed in US waters went up drastically after 1975, and the Food and Agruculture Orginization estimates 800,000 tons of sharks are killed each year in the United States alone.

properties.name: Atlantic Slave Trade
properties.type: Tactics of Fear Through the Use of Sharks
properties.location: The location chosen for this topic is Maryland, as it was the hub of the slave trade in the United States in 1660.
properties.facts:
The Atlantic Slave Trade has a lot of untaught horrors which are still being recovered, one of which involved the fear tactic of sharks for slaves on boats. 
 
  Transporters would throw slaves overboard, sometimes baiting the water first, for a variety of reasons, including food shortages, disciplinary actions, sadistic pleasure, setting of examples, etc. 
 
 This ingrained a fear of sharks in not only enslaved culture, but in the culture of the slave owners and citizens who heard the tales of the boats. 
 
 This reinforced in society the mysticism of sharks and the power that they held. Many artists took these events and accounts and made works based off of the trauma and fear these people thrown overboard experienced.
properties.imageCaption: Rendering of Slaves Being Thrown Overboard to Hungry Sharks
properties.source: "History from below the water line: Sharks and the Atlantic slave trade" by Marcus Rediker

properties.name: Kāmohoaliʻi
properties.type: Shark Diety and Protector of Humans
properties.location: Located in Hawaii and is said to roam all of the Islands
properties.facts:
This spirit is said to have it's origins in leading sailors back to their homes. Kāmohoaliʻi would shake his tale, and the fishermen and sailors would give him offerings in order to get safe and quick passage. 
 
 Kāmohoaliʻi is still a prevelant shark spirit in Hawaiian culture and is known as a powerful and benevolent entity. 
 
 There are still many who worship this shark for its great service to the poeple of the islands. Kāmohoaliʻi is said to have lead the original Hawaiians to the islands. 
 
  Hawaii was the first state in the nation to ban the sale of shark fins and shark fin products, citing the importance of sharks role in the ocean.
properties.imageCaption: The Journey of Pele, Painted by Herb Kawainui Kane
properties.source: <i>Hawaiian Folk Tales</> by Thomas G. Thrum

properties.name: The Leg Of Nohi Abassi
properties.location: The location chosen for this myth is Brazil, even though it is a popular myth in Guiana as well. Brazil was chosen because it was where the myth originated, which subsequently transfered over after the colinization of Guiana.
properties.facts:
This myth shows the power that sharks can posess, and paints them as easily swayed. 
 
 The Leg Of Nohi Abassi is an explanation for the creation of Orion's Belt, which was thought to be the leg of the Hunter Nohi Abassi. 
 
 Nohi had grown annoyed with his mother-in-law, so much so that he had trained a shark to hunt and eat her. When the mother-in-law caught wind of this, she turned her other daughter into a shark and trained her to harm Abassi. 
 
 When the time was right, the sister sawed off Abassi's leg with her teeth. Legend has it that the leg then became Orion's Belt. 
 
  This negative image of sharks as tools of distruction could be used as a cultural explanation for the illegal killing of more than 300,000 sharks off of the coast of Brazil each year.

properties.name: The Myth of Lamia
properties.type: The Story of Hera's Jealousy and Lamia's Revenge
properties.facts:
Lamia was the daughter of Posiden. Lamia began getting close with Zues, and an affair ensued. This enraged Hera when she found out about it, and as revenge, she decided to steal all of Lamia's children and murder them. 
 
 Lamia was distraught, and to help her get back at Hera, Zues decided to turn her into a ferocious shark with the intent of murdering innocent children to get back at Hera. She will forever roam the waters in search of children to kill in order to hurt Hera. 
 
 This myth paints sharks as violent and malicous. It portrays them as blood hungry, and influenced people into thinking that all sharks were bad and out to eat their children.
properties.source: Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology, Volume 2 By Sir William Smith

properties.name: The Yanyuwa Language
properties.type: Dialects Originating from Sharks and the Ocean
properties.facts:
The language of Yanyuwa is an Australian Aboriginal language that has its roots in the ocean. The language developed over time with the help of the surrounding bodies of water and the creatures found within. 
 
 The oldest myth that comes from these people is called the Tiger Shark Dreaming, which is 40,000 years old. It details the journey of a tiger shark, who begins the tale having a very bad day. The tiger shark was being picked on by the other sharks and fish, and finally decided to take some of his hammerhead and stingray friends, and haul off the find a new place to call home. This journey created the rivers, water holes, and formations of Australia today. 
 
 The Yanyuwa people have just recently gotten some land back from the Australian government which was taken during the attempted genocide against the aboriginal people of Australia. The land was given back in order to help the prosperity and vivacity of the people and the surrouding wildlife. 
 
 Australia as a whole catches over 1200 tonnes of shark each year, where as aboriginal people account to little to none of that figure. This is because of their respect and honor shown to sharks in their culture and language.
properties.source: Australia's Ancient Language Shaped by Sharks By Georgina Kenyon

properties.name: Shark Fin Soup
properties.facts:
This traditional cutural dish from China dates back all the way to the Song dynasty, which ruled from 960 to 1279 CE, split over two rules, the Nothern Song and the Southern Song dynasty. 
 
The Song dynasty created the tradition of eating shark fin soup because of the power and distinction it gave them, as it was risky to hunt for sharks with their technology, making it a food reserved for only the wealthiest of families. 
 
 This tradition continues due to this older truth, even though the technology we have today makes sharks easy to hunt. China kills an estimated 100 millions sharks a year, which mainly go to feed the tradition of shark fin soup.
properties.imageCaption: The shark fin trade is thought to kill more than 70 million sharks each year (Photo: Shutterstock)
